canonical_explanation.text: Chemistry plays a vital role in everyday life through drugs, food chemicals, and cleansing agents. Drugs are classified by their therapeutic action: analgesics (pain relievers), tranquilizers (sedatives), antiseptics, disinfectants, antimicrobials (antibiotics), antifertility drugs, antacids, and antihistamines. Drug-target interactions primarily involve enzymes (as competitive or non-competitive inhibitors) and receptors (agonists or antagonists). Chemicals in food include artificial sweeteners (aspartame, saccharin, sucralose), food preservatives (sodium benzoate, sorbic acid), and antioxidants (BHA, BHT). Soaps are sodium or potassium salts of long-chain fatty acids formed by saponification, and they clean by forming micelles around grease/oil. Synthetic detergents are classified as anionic, cationic, and non-ionic, and unlike soaps, they work in hard water.
rules: Drugs interact with targets by binding to enzyme active sites (competitive inhibition) or allosteric sites (non-competitive inhibition), or by binding to receptors to trigger/block biological responses.

Soaps form micelles with the hydrophobic tail dissolving grease and the hydrophilic head pointing outward into water; they do not work well in hard water due to formation of insoluble calcium/magnesium salts.
Synthetic detergents are sulphonate or sulphate salts (anionic), quaternary ammonium salts (cationic), or polyethylene glycol ethers (non-ionic), and they work in both soft and hard water.

questions.question_text: Analgesics are drugs that:
questions.explanation_correct: Analgesics are drugs that relieve pain by interacting with pain receptors in the body, blocking the transmission of pain signals to the brain. This makes them effective for reducing various types of pain, such as headaches, muscle aches, or joint pain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Analgesics are not drugs that reduce fever (that would be antipyretics), kill bacteria (that would be antibiotics), or reduce anxiety (that would be tranquilizers or sedatives). Analgesics specifically target and relieve pain, which is why option B is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) is classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: Aspirin is classified as a non-narcotic analgesic and antipyretic, which means it is a pain reliever and fever reducer without the addictive properties of narcotics. It works by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins, which are involved in inflammation and pain signaling.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aspirin is not a tranquilizer, as it does not have a sedative effect. It is also not an antibiotic, as it does not kill or inhibit the growth of microorganisms. Aspirin is also not an antihistamine, as it does not work by blocking histamine receptors in the body.

questions.question_text: Antiseptics are applied to:
questions.explanation_correct: Antiseptics are applied to living tissues to prevent infection by killing or inhibiting the growth of microorganisms, such as bacteria and fungi. They are used to disinfect and sterilize the skin and other body surfaces to prevent the spread of infectious diseases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antiseptics are not used on non-living surfaces or for food preservation. They are specifically used on living tissues to kill or prevent the growth of microorganisms and stop the spread of infections. Disinfectants are used for non-living surfaces, while food preservatives are used to prevent spoilage in food.

questions.question_text: Disinfectants are applied to:
questions.explanation_correct: Disinfectants are applied to non-living surfaces such as floors, drainage systems, and instruments to kill microorganisms like bacteria, viruses, and fungi and prevent the spread of diseases. They are not used on living tissues or food, which require different types of chemicals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Disinfectants are not applied to living tissues as they can be harmful to the body. They are also not used on food, which requires different types of food-safe chemicals for preservation and sanitation. Disinfectants are specifically used to clean and sterilize non-living surfaces like floors, drains, and medical equipment to prevent the spread of infections.

questions.question_text: Penicillin is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Penicillin is an antibiotic, which is a type of drug that kills or inhibits the growth of bacteria. Antibiotics are used to treat bacterial infections and do not have the effects of analgesics (pain relievers), tranquilizers (sedatives), or antacids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Penicillin is an antibiotic, not an analgesic (pain reliever), tranquilizer (sedative), or antacid. Antibiotics work by interfering with the growth and reproduction of bacteria, allowing the body's immune system to fight off the infection. They are not used to relieve pain, induce sedation, or neutralize stomach acid like the other drug classes mentioned in the options.

questions.question_text: Antacids work by:

options.text: Neutralising excess hydrochloric acid in the stomach

questions.explanation_correct: Antacids work by neutralizing excess hydrochloric acid in the stomach, reducing the acidity and relieving symptoms of heartburn or indigestion. They do this by reacting with the acid to form less acidic compounds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antacids do not kill bacteria in the stomach, nor do they increase acid production or dissolve food particles. Their primary function is to neutralize the excess stomach acid, which is the main cause of heartburn and discomfort. Killing bacteria, increasing acid, or dissolving food are not the mechanisms by which antacids provide relief.

questions.question_text: Antihistamines are drugs that:

options.text: Counteract the effects of histamine, relieving allergy symptoms

questions.explanation_correct: Antihistamines are drugs that counteract the effects of histamine, a chemical released by the body during an allergic reaction. By blocking the receptors for histamine, antihistamines relieve allergy symptoms like sneezing, itching, and swelling.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antihistamines do not kill viruses, increase blood pressure, or act as preservatives. They work by blocking the receptors for histamine, a chemical that causes allergy symptoms like sneezing and itching. By counteracting the effects of histamine, antihistamines provide relief from allergic reactions.

questions.question_text: Drug-target interaction involving an enzyme where the drug binds to the active site and prevents the substrate from binding is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Competitive inhibition occurs when a drug binds to the active site of an enzyme, preventing the substrate from binding. This blocks the enzyme's normal function, making it an effective drug-target interaction to treat various medical conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Non-competitive inhibition involves the drug binding to a site other than the active site, which causes a change in the enzyme's shape and reduces its activity. Allosteric activation refers to a drug binding to a site that enhances the enzyme's activity. Irreversible binding is when the drug permanently attaches to the enzyme, inactivating it.

questions.question_text: Morphine is classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: Morphine is classified as a narcotic analgesic, which means it is a pain-relieving drug derived from opium. Narcotic analgesics work by binding to and activating opioid receptors in the brain, which reduces the perception of pain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Morphine is not a non-narcotic analgesic, tranquilizer, or antibiotic. Non-narcotic analgesics like acetaminophen and ibuprofen do not have the same potent pain-relieving effects as narcotic analgesics like morphine, which is derived from the opium poppy. Tranquilizers and antibiotics have different mechanisms of action and therapeutic uses compared to narcotic analgesics.

questions.question_text: Cimetidine (Tagamet) is an example of an:

options.text: Antacid that acts as a histamine H2-receptor antagonist

questions.explanation_correct: Cimetidine is an antacid that acts as a histamine H2-receptor antagonist. It works by blocking the action of histamine at the H2 receptors in the stomach, reducing the production of stomach acid and providing relief from acid reflux and ulcers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cimetidine is not an analgesic (pain reliever), antibiotic, or tranquilizer. It is a specific type of antacid that targets the histamine H2 receptors in the stomach to reduce acid production, rather than working as a general pain reliever, antimicrobial, or sedative drug.

questions.question_text: Saccharin is used as an artificial sweetener because it is:

options.text: About 550 times sweeter than sucrose but provides no calories

questions.explanation_correct: Saccharin is an artificial sweetener that is about 550 times sweeter than regular sugar (sucrose) but contains no calories, making it a popular sugar substitute in foods and drinks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Saccharin is not a natural sugar - it is an artificial sweetener that is synthesized in a lab. It is much sweeter than regular sugar, which is why it is used in small quantities to provide sweetness without the extra calories from sugar.

questions.question_text: Sodium benzoate is used as a:
questions.explanation_correct: Sodium benzoate is used as a food preservative to prevent the growth of mold, yeast, and bacteria in food products. It inhibits the metabolic activities of microorganisms, thus increasing the shelf life of the food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium benzoate is not an artificial sweetener, antioxidant, or food colouring. It is a common food preservative used to extend the shelf life of various food and beverage products by preventing microbial growth. The correct answer is that sodium benzoate is used as a food preservative.

questions.question_text: BHA and BHT are added to food as:

options.text: Antioxidants to prevent oxidative rancidity of fats

questions.explanation_correct: BHA (butylated hydroxyanisole) and BHT (butylated hydroxytoluene) are added to food as antioxidants to prevent the oxidative rancidity of fats and oils, which can cause undesirable changes in flavor and odor. They work by inhibiting the chain reaction of lipid oxidation, thereby preserving the freshness and quality of food products.
questions.explanation_incorrect: BHA and BHT are not artificial sweeteners, emulsifiers, or flavouring agents. They are specifically used as antioxidants in food to prevent the oxidation of fats and oils, which can lead to spoilage and rancidity. Artificial sweeteners like aspartame, saccharin, and sucralose are used to provide sweetness without the calories, while emulsifiers help to stabilize the mixture of water and oil in food products.

questions.question_text: Aspartame is an artificial sweetener that is not suitable for:
questions.explanation_correct: Aspartame is an artificial sweetener that decomposes when exposed to high temperatures, such as during cooking or baking. This makes it unsuitable for use in food preparation that involves high heat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aspartame is a safe and widely used artificial sweetener. It is suitable for use by diabetics and can be added to both hot and cold drinks. However, it is not suitable for cooking or baking at high temperatures, as the heat causes it to decompose and lose its sweetening properties.

questions.question_text: Soap is chemically a sodium or potassium salt of:
questions.explanation_correct: Soap is chemically a sodium or potassium salt of long-chain fatty acids, which are formed through the saponification reaction between fatty acids and sodium or potassium hydroxide. This is the correct option because soaps are made by this process and have these specific chemical structures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Soaps are not made from mineral acids, amino acids, or nucleic acids. These are different types of chemical compounds with distinct structures and properties. Soaps are specifically produced by reacting fatty acids with sodium or potassium hydroxide, forming the salt of the fatty acid, which is the key ingredient in soap.

questions.question_text: The process of making soap from fats and alkali is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The process of making soap from fats and alkali is called saponification. In this process, the long-chain fatty acids in fats react with a strong base like sodium or potassium hydroxide to form soap (sodium or potassium salts of fatty acids).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The process of making soap is not esterification, hydrogenation, or polymerization. Esterification involves the reaction between an alcohol and a carboxylic acid to form an ester. Hydrogenation is the process of adding hydrogen to unsaturated fats to make them more saturated. Polymerization is the formation of large molecules from smaller monomers. The correct process for making soap is saponification, where fats and alkali react to form soap and glycerol.

questions.question_text: Soaps do not work well in hard water because:

options.text: They form insoluble calcium and magnesium salts (scum)
Hard water is too hot for soaps
Hard water has too much dissolved oxygen

questions.explanation_correct: Soaps do not work well in hard water because they form insoluble calcium and magnesium salts, known as 'scum'. This scum prevents the soap from effectively cleaning the surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Soaps do not decompose in hard water. Instead, the calcium and magnesium ions in hard water react with the soap molecules to form an insoluble precipitate, or scum. This scum reduces the cleaning ability of the soap, making it less effective. The temperature of the water and the amount of dissolved oxygen are not the reasons why soaps do not work well in hard water.

questions.question_text: Synthetic detergents work in hard water because:

options.text: Their calcium and magnesium salts are soluble in water

questions.explanation_correct: Synthetic detergents work in hard water because their calcium and magnesium salts are soluble in water. This means they do not form insoluble precipitates with the calcium and magnesium ions present in hard water, unlike soap which forms scum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is correct because synthetic detergents contain both hydrophilic (water-loving) and hydrophobic (water-hating) parts. The hydrophobic part allows them to trap grease and oil, while the hydrophilic part keeps them soluble in water. They also form micelles around dirt, but their ability to work in hard water is specifically due to their soluble calcium and magnesium salts.

questions.question_text: An example of a cationic detergent is:
questions.explanation_correct: Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide is a cationic detergent, as it has a positively charged head group (the nitrogen atom with three methyl groups) that attracts and binds to negatively charged surfaces, making it effective for cleaning.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium lauryl sulphate is an anionic detergent, meaning it has a negatively charged head group. Sodium dodecylbenzenesulphonate is also an anionic detergent. Polyethylene glycol stearate is a non-ionic detergent, with no charge on the head group. Only cetyltrimethylammonium bromide, with its positively charged head group, is a cationic detergent.

questions.question_text: The cleaning action of soap involves formation of:

options.text: Micelles where the hydrophobic tails trap grease and hydrophilic heads face water

questions.explanation_correct: The cleaning action of soap involves the formation of micelles, where the hydrophobic (water-repelling) tails of the soap molecules trap grease and dirt, while the hydrophilic (water-attracting) heads face outwards towards the water. This allows the trapped dirt and grease to be washed away.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cleaning action of soap does not involve the formation of emulsions, precipitates, or chemical reactions with dirt. Soap works by forming micelles that encapsulate the dirt and grease, allowing them to be easily rinsed away. The hydrophobic tails of the soap molecules attach to the non-polar dirt and grease, while the hydrophilic heads face the water, enabling the removal of the unwanted substances.

questions.question_text: Broad-spectrum antibiotics are effective against:

options.text: A wide range of gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria

questions.explanation_correct: Broad-spectrum antibiotics are effective against a wide range of both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria. This means they can kill or inhibit the growth of many different types of harmful bacteria, making them useful for treating a variety of bacterial infections.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Broad-spectrum antibiotics are not just effective against viruses or fungi alone. They are called 'broad-spectrum' because they can target a broad range of bacterial species, including both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria. This makes them more versatile and effective compared to antibiotics that only work on a specific type of bacteria.

questions.question_text: Tranquilizers are drugs used to treat:
questions.explanation_correct: Tranquilizers are drugs used to treat mental anxiety and stress by acting on the central nervous system to induce a calming effect. This makes option B the correct answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tranquilizers are not used to treat bacterial infections, heart diseases, or diabetes. These conditions require different types of medications that target the specific underlying causes. Instead, tranquilizers work by affecting the brain and nervous system to reduce feelings of anxiety and stress.

questions.question_text: Norethindrone is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Norethindrone is an example of an antifertility drug, as it is a synthetic progestin hormone used in oral contraceptives to prevent pregnancy by inhibiting ovulation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Norethindrone is not an analgesic (pain reliever), antibiotic, or antacid. It is a synthetic progestin hormone used in birth control pills to prevent pregnancy by inhibiting ovulation, making it an antifertility drug.

questions.question_text: Sorbic acid is used as a:
questions.explanation_correct: Sorbic acid is a food preservative that acts as an antimicrobial agent, inhibiting the growth of fungi, bacteria, and other microorganisms in food. This helps extend the shelf life of food products.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sorbic acid is not an artificial sweetener, antioxidant, or food coloring agent. It is a preservative that is added to food to prevent spoilage and microbial growth. The other options are not the primary uses of sorbic acid in food chemistry.

questions.question_text: Non-ionic detergents are formed from:

options.text: Polyethylene glycol and stearic acid (esters with no ionic groups)

questions.explanation_correct: Non-ionic detergents are formed from polyethylene glycol and stearic acid (esters with no ionic groups). This means they do not have any charged (ionic) groups, making them non-ionic in nature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because: A) Long-chain sulphonic acids are anionic detergents, not non-ionic. C) Quaternary ammonium salts are cationic detergents, not non-ionic. D) Sodium salts of fatty acids are soaps, not synthetic non-ionic detergents.

questions.question_text: Tincture of iodine (2-3% I2 in alcohol-water) is used as an:
questions.explanation_correct: Tincture of iodine is used as an antiseptic because iodine is a strong oxidizing agent that can kill bacteria, viruses, and fungi on the skin. It is used to disinfect minor cuts, scrapes, and burns to prevent infection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tincture of iodine is not an analgesic (pain reliever), antacid, or tranquilizer (sedative). It is specifically used as an antiseptic to kill microbes on the skin and prevent infections. The other options are incorrect because they describe different therapeutic actions of drugs, which do not match the purpose of using tincture of iodine.

questions.question_text: Chloramphenicol is a broad-spectrum:
questions.explanation_correct: Chloramphenicol is a broad-spectrum antibiotic, meaning it can kill a wide range of bacteria. Antibiotics are drugs that work against bacterial infections, so the correct answer is that chloramphenicol is a broad-spectrum antibiotic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chloramphenicol is not an analgesic (pain reliever), antacid, or sweetener. It is a type of antibiotic, which are drugs that kill or stop the growth of bacteria. Antibiotics are used to treat bacterial infections, not to relieve pain, neutralize stomach acid, or provide sweetness.

questions.question_text: The purpose of adding antioxidants to food is to:

options.text: Prevent oxidation and rancidity of fats and oils

questions.explanation_correct: Antioxidants are added to food to prevent the oxidation and rancidity of fats and oils. They work by inhibiting the chemical reactions that lead to the breakdown and spoilage of these food components.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antioxidants are not added to food to make it sweeter, kill microorganisms, or add color. These are not the primary functions of antioxidants in food. Antioxidants like BHA and BHT prevent the oxidation of fats and oils, which can lead to rancidity and spoilage of the food product.

questions.question_text: Anionic detergents contain which type of charged group?

options.text: Negatively charged head group (sulphonate or sulphate)

questions.explanation_correct: Anionic detergents contain a negatively charged head group, typically a sulphonate or sulphate group. This negative charge allows the detergent to effectively interact with and solubilize grease and dirt, making it an effective cleaning agent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Anionic detergents do not contain a positively charged head group (option A) or a combination of positive and negative charges (option D). They also do not lack a charged group (option C). The key feature of anionic detergents is the negatively charged sulphonate or sulphate group, which gives them their cleaning power.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a correct drug-use pairing?
questions.explanation_correct: Penicillin is an antibiotic, not a tranquilizer. Tranquilizers are drugs that reduce anxiety, tension, and agitation, while antibiotics like penicillin are used to treat bacterial infections.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Paracetamol is correctly paired as an analgesic (pain-relieving) and antipyretic (fever-reducing) drug. Ranitidine is also correctly paired as an antacid that blocks H2 receptors in the stomach. Chloroxylenol (Dettol) is correctly paired as an antiseptic that kills germs on the skin. However, penicillin is an antibiotic, not a tranquilizer, so that pairing is incorrect.

questions.question_text: Sodium dodecylbenzenesulphonate is an example of an:
questions.explanation_correct: Sodium dodecylbenzenesulphonate is an example of an anionic detergent. Anionic detergents have a negatively charged head group, which interacts with dirt and grease to lift and remove them from surfaces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium dodecylbenzenesulphonate is not a cationic detergent, which has a positively charged head group, nor a non-ionic detergent, which has no charge. It is also not a soap, which is a sodium or potassium salt of a long-chain fatty acid. Sodium dodecylbenzenesulphonate is specifically an anionic detergent, with a negatively charged sulphonate group that helps remove dirt and oil from surfaces.

questions.question_text: Equanil (meprobamate) is used as a:
questions.explanation_correct: Equanil (meprobamate) is a tranquilizer, which is a type of drug that has a calming and sedative effect on the central nervous system. This makes it useful for treating anxiety and insomnia.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equanil is not an antibiotic, which are used to kill or inhibit the growth of bacteria. It is also not an analgesic, which is a pain reliever, or an antiseptic, which is a disinfectant used to prevent infection. Equanil is classified as a tranquilizer, which means it has a calming effect on the mind and body.

questions.question_text: Sucralose is an artificial sweetener derived from:
questions.explanation_correct: Sucralose is an artificial sweetener derived from sucrose (table sugar) by selective chlorination. The chlorination process replaces three hydrogen-oxygen groups on the sucrose molecule with three chlorine atoms, making it much sweeter than regular sugar while remaining indigestible to the human body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sucralose is not derived from glucose, fructose, or starch. It is made by selectively replacing hydroxyl groups on the sucrose molecule with chlorine atoms, a process that makes it much sweeter than regular sugar while making it non-caloric and non-metabolizable by the human body.

questions.question_text: Cationic detergents like cetyltrimethylammonium bromide have:

options.text: Germicidal properties and are used in hair conditioners

questions.explanation_correct: Cationic detergents like cetyltrimethylammonium bromide have a positive charge and possess antimicrobial (germicidal) properties, which makes them useful in hair conditioners and other personal care products.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cationic detergents have a positive charge, which allows them to interact with negatively charged surfaces like hair, skin, and microbes. This gives them cleaning and antimicrobial properties, unlike the other options which do not correctly describe the properties of cationic detergents.

questions.question_text: Phenol (1% solution) is used as a:
questions.explanation_correct: Phenol is used as a disinfectant due to its antimicrobial properties. It is an effective antiseptic and can kill bacteria, viruses, and fungi, making it suitable for disinfecting surfaces and medical equipment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Phenol is not used as a sweetener, analgesic, or antacid. Sweeteners are compounds like aspartame or saccharin that provide a sweet taste without calories. Analgesics are pain relievers, and antacids are used to neutralize stomach acid. Phenol is an antiseptic and disinfectant due to its ability to kill microorganisms, not for these other functions.

questions.question_text: Antiseptics and disinfectants serve the same purpose but differ in the concentration used and where they are applied.
questions.explanation_correct: Antiseptics and disinfectants both kill or inhibit the growth of microorganisms, but they differ in the concentration used and where they are applied. Antiseptics are used on living tissue (like skin) at lower concentrations, while disinfectants are used on non-living surfaces at higher concentrations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Antiseptics and disinfectants serve the same purpose of killing or inhibiting microorganisms, but they differ in the concentration used and where they are applied. Antiseptics are used on living tissue like skin at lower concentrations, while disinfectants are used on non-living surfaces at higher concentrations to be more effective.

questions.question_text: Artificial sweeteners like saccharin provide the same caloric value as sugar.
questions.explanation_correct: Artificial sweeteners like saccharin do not provide the same caloric value as sugar. Artificial sweeteners are non-nutritive, meaning they have virtually no calories, in contrast to regular sugar which is a carbohydrate with 4 calories per gram.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false because artificial sweeteners like saccharin have negligible caloric value compared to sugar. Sugar is a carbohydrate that provides 4 calories per gram, while artificial sweeteners are non-nutritive and have virtually no calories. This allows them to be used as a lower-calorie alternative to sugar.

questions.question_text: Soaps are effective cleansing agents in hard water.
questions.explanation_correct: Soaps are not effective cleansing agents in hard water because the calcium and magnesium ions in hard water react with the soap to form an insoluble scum, reducing the soap's cleaning ability.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false because soaps are not effective in hard water. Hard water contains dissolved minerals like calcium and magnesium, which react with the soap to form an insoluble precipitate. This precipitate reduces the soap's ability to clean effectively by preventing the soap from forming micelles around grease and dirt. Synthetic detergents, on the other hand, work better in hard water as they are not affected by the mineral ions.

questions.question_text: Narcotic analgesics like morphine can cause addiction and are therefore controlled substances.
questions.explanation_correct: Narcotic analgesics like morphine can cause physical and psychological addiction, and are therefore controlled substances that require a doctor's prescription to obtain legally. This is because they have a high potential for abuse and misuse.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Narcotic analgesics like morphine are powerful pain relievers that can produce a sense of euphoria or 'high'. However, they also have a high risk of dependence and addiction, which is why they are classified as controlled substances and their use is regulated. Prolonged or non-medical use of these drugs can lead to physical and psychological addiction, which is why they require a doctor's prescription.

questions.question_text: Biodegradable detergents have unbranched hydrocarbon chains that are easily decomposed by microorganisms.
questions.explanation_correct: Biodegradable detergents have unbranched hydrocarbon chains that are easily broken down by microorganisms, allowing them to be decomposed in the environment. This makes them more environmentally friendly compared to non-biodegradable detergents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Biodegradable detergents have straight, unbranched hydrocarbon chains that can be easily decomposed by microorganisms in the environment. Non-biodegradable detergents often have branched hydrocarbon chains that are more resistant to microbial breakdown, making them less environmentally friendly.

questions.question_text: Drugs that reduce body temperature in fever are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Drugs that reduce body temperature in fever are called antipyretics. This is because 'antipyretic' means 'reducing fever', so these drugs specifically work to lower the elevated body temperature caused by a fever.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'antipyretics'. Drugs that reduce pain are called analgesics, while drugs that act as sedatives are called tranquilizers. Antipyretics are a specific class of drugs that work to bring down a fever by lowering the body's temperature.

questions.question_text: BHA stands for ___.
questions.explanation_correct: BHA stands for butylated hydroxyanisole, which is an antioxidant commonly used as a food preservative. Antioxidants like BHA help prevent food from spoiling by inhibiting the oxidation of fats and oils, which can lead to rancidity and off-flavors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: BHA does not stand for 'butylated hydroxyantioxidant'. The correct answer is 'butylated hydroxyanisole', which is the full name of the chemical compound BHA. BHA is a specific type of antioxidant that is widely used in foods and other consumer products to prevent oxidation and spoilage.

questions.question_text: The process of making soap by hydrolysis of fats with NaOH is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The process of making soap by hydrolysis of fats with sodium hydroxide (NaOH) is called saponification. This is because the reaction between fats and NaOH produces sodium salts of long-chain fatty acids, which are the main components of soap.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'saponification'. Saponification is the chemical process where fats or oils are reacted with a strong base, such as sodium hydroxide (NaOH), to produce glycerol and the sodium salts of fatty acids, which are the main components of soap. This reaction is essential for making soap, which is a common cleaning agent used in everyday life.

questions.question_text: A drug that blocks the action of histamine at H1 receptors and is used to treat allergies is called an ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is 'antihistamine' because this type of drug blocks the action of histamine at H1 receptors, which helps treat allergic symptoms like sneezing, itching, and redness.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'antihistamine'. Antihistamines are drugs that work by blocking the action of histamine, a chemical in the body that causes allergy symptoms. They do this by binding to and inactivating histamine receptors, which prevents histamine from triggering the allergic response. Therefore, antihistamines are the correct type of drug used to treat allergies.

questions.question_text: In a micelle, the ___ (hydrocarbon) tails point inward and the ___ heads point outward towards water.
questions.explanation_correct: In a micelle, the hydrophobic (water-repelling) hydrocarbon tails of the surfactant molecules point inward, away from the water, while the hydrophilic (water-attracting) heads point outward towards the water. This arrangement helps the micelle stabilize and effectively trap grease or oil inside.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be 'polar and non-polar' instead of 'hydrophobic and hydrophilic'. In a micelle, the hydrocarbon tails are hydrophobic (non-polar) and point inward, while the hydrophilic (polar) heads point outward towards the water. The correct answer in the exact format required is 'hydrophobic and hydrophilic'.

questions.question_text: Sodium benzoate and sorbic acid are commonly used food ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Sodium benzoate and sorbic acid are commonly used food preservatives. Preservatives like these help prevent food spoilage and increase the shelf life of food products by inhibiting the growth of microorganisms such as bacteria, molds, and yeast.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'preservatives'. Sodium benzoate and sorbic acid are added to food products to act as preservatives, which help extend the shelf life of the food by preventing microbial growth and spoilage. They are not classified as other types of food chemicals like sweeteners or antioxidants.

questions.question_text: Drugs that interact with biological targets such as enzymes and ___ are the basis of pharmacological action.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is 'receptors' because drugs primarily interact with biological targets like enzymes and receptors to produce their pharmacological effects. Receptors are the molecules that drugs bind to and activate or block, leading to a physiological response in the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'receptors'. The question is asking about the biological targets that drugs interact with to produce their effects. While enzymes are one type of target, the key targets are actually receptors. Drugs bind to and activate or block receptors, which then trigger a physiological response in the body.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following detergent types by their charge: (A) Anionic (negative), (B) Cationic (positive), (C) Non-ionic (no charge). Order from negative to positive charge.
questions.explanation_correct: The order of detergent types from negative to positive charge is A (anionic), C (non-ionic), B (cationic). Anionic detergents have a negatively charged head group, non-ionic detergents have no charge, and cationic detergents have a positively charged head group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be A, B, C. This is wrong because cationic detergents (B) have a positive charge, while anionic detergents (A) have a negative charge. Non-ionic detergents (C) have no charge. The correct order from negative to positive charge is A, C, B.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following drugs by their primary action: (A) Paracetamol - Analgesic/Antipyretic, (B) Amoxicillin - Antibiotic, (C) Ranitidine - Antacid, (D) Chloroxylenol - Antiseptic. Order as: pain relief, infection, stomach, surface application.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is A, B, C, D because Paracetamol is an analgesic (pain reliever), Amoxicillin is an antibiotic (treats infections), Ranitidine is an antacid (for stomach issues), and Chloroxylenol is an antiseptic (for surface application).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be mixing up the drug classes. For example, placing Amoxicillin as a pain reliever or Ranitidine as an antiseptic would be wrong, as these drugs have different primary actions from what their classifications indicate.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following artificial sweeteners in order of increasing sweetness relative to sucrose: (A) Aspartame (~200 times), (B) Saccharin (~550 times), (C) Sucralose (~600 times).
questions.explanation_correct: The sweetness of artificial sweeteners is relative to sucrose, the common sugar. Aspartame is about 200 times sweeter than sucrose, saccharin is about 550 times sweeter, and sucralose is the sweetest at around 600 times the sweetness of sucrose. So the order from least to most sweet is A, B, C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order of increasing sweetness is not A, B, C. This is because saccharin is sweeter than aspartame, and sucralose is the sweetest of the three. The correct order from least to most sweet is A, B, C - aspartame, saccharin, and sucralose.
